First, many GMO crops are engineered to be resistant to herbicides like glyphosate. This leads to much higher levels of these toxic chemicals in our food supply. Studies have linked glyphosate to cancer, hormonal disruption, and other health issues. By consuming GMO foods, we are exposing ourselves to these risks.

Second, GMOs often contain foreign DNA from other species, which our bodies have never encountered before. There is no long-term safety data on the impacts this novel DNA could have on human health. It has the potential to trigger allergic reactions or even alter our own DNA and genes in unpredictable ways. 

Third, many GMO crops produce their own pesticides. The Bt toxin produced by GMO corn, for example, has been found to damage the cells lining human blood vessels. This could potentially lead to serious health conditions like leaky gut syndrome.

Finally, the overall nutrient content and quality of GMO foods is often lower than non-GMO alternatives. GMO soy, for instance, has been shown to contain significantly lower levels of phytoestrogens, which are beneficial antioxidants. Lower nutrient levels in our food can contribute to deficiencies and chronic health issues over time.

In summary, the presence of toxic herbicides, foreign DNA, built-in pesticides, and lower nutrient levels make a compelling case that GMO foods may pose real risks to our health. Much more long-term, independent safety testing is needed before we can consider them safe for human consumption. Until then, it's best to avoid them whenever possible.
